content.question: The base of a solid is the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="y equals, sine x " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to pi " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. For the solid, each cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is an equilateral triangle. What is the volume of the solid?

topic.text: 8.8: Volumes with Cross Sections - Triangles and Semicircles

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
